awd_titl_txt: Carbon-dioxide and Oxygen Counter-permeable Membrane Reactor for  Hydrogen/Syngas Production from Natural Gas
awd_abstract_narration:
The discovery of vast natural gas reserves in the U.S., consisting primarily of methane, has led to a revolution in the US energy and chemical sectors. Significant research activities are currently being devoted towards the development of techniques for efficient conversion of natural gas to hydrogen or syngas. Hydrogen is a clean fuel, while syngas, a mixture of hydrogen and carbon monoxide, is an important feedstock for the synthesis of a large number of chemical products.  This project aims to develop a new membrane reactor for oxidative steam reforming of natural gas to hydrogen or syngas. The new reactor is based on novel ceramic membranes that allow selective counter-permeation of oxygen and carbon dioxide. Preliminary data suggest that this approach leads to improved yields, is more energy efficient, and allows for longer operation of the reactor, due to reduced carbon deposits. 

The use of novel ceramic-carbonate dual-phase membranes for autothermal oxidative steam reforming of natural gas to hydrogen or syngas has potential for significant industrial impact. The dual-phase membranes offer significant advantages over existing methods, due to improved energy and cost efficiency. The project will focus on improving membrane performance to enable efficient counter-permeation of carbon dioxide and oxygen during oxidative steam reforming of natural gas. The project will involve experiments using a prototype membrane reactor and modeling to understand the underlying chemical and transport mechanisms. The ultimate objective is to optimize the operating conditions of the reactor for production of either hydrogen or syngas. The simultaneous separation of carbon dioxide and controlled addition of oxygen into the reacting mixture is an innovative and potentially transformative idea that may lead to significant improvements in energy and cost efficiency. The PI plans to train graduate and undergraduate students in membrane science, chemical reaction engineering, ceramic processing, separation processes, and ionic conducting materials. Research results will be disseminated to the scientific community through journal publications and conference presentations and will be included in course materials and workshop lectures. The PI plans to incorporate results from this project into a Science is Fun program to improve the awareness of K-12 students on energy production, carbon dioxide emissions and membrane science, while motivating their interests in pursuing a STEM career path.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ele.pgm_ele_name: Proc Sys, Reac Eng & Mol Therm

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Hydrogen is a clean fuel for electricity generation, and both hydrogen and syngas are important feedstocks for synthesis of many chemical products. However, current processes for hydrogen production require air separation, carbon dioxide removal and product purification, and thus are energy-intensive. This project was focused on studying a new membrane reactor based on a ceramic-carbonate dual-phase membrane for conversion of natural gas (methane) to high purity hydrogen with simultaneous capture of carbon dioxide.  Research conducted in this project was directed towards optimizing synthesis and structure of the ceramic-carbonate dual-phase membranes, understanding carbon dioxide and oxygen permeation and co-permeation properties of these membranes under methane steam-reforming operation conditions, and investigating the operation of the dual-phase membrane reactor for methane steam reforming with carbon dioxide removal. 

Key outcomes of this project include synthesis of several ceramic-carbonate dual-phase membranes permeable only to carbon dioxide with high permeation flux at high temperatures,  improved understanding of carbon dioxide and oxygen permeation and counter-permeation properties and chemical stability of these membranes under the operation conditions of converting methane to hydrogen, and experimental verification that carbon dioxide removal during methane conversion reaction in the ceramic-carbonate dual-phase membrane reactor can produce high purity hydrogen in a single-stage membrane reactor. Experimental and modeling results predict that at a feed pressure of 5 atm and applying vacuum at the sweep side of the membrane reactor, the membrane reactor can achieve over 99% methane conversion, hydrogen yield, and carbon dioxide recovery and essentially produces CO-free pure hydrogen retentate stream at sufficiently high steam-reforming of methane reaction rate and carbon dioxide permeation flux. As a result, the reactor footprint for hydrogen production can be significantly reduced as no extra reaction and separation units are needed.

These project outcomes are important to the fundamental understanding and development of high-temperature inorganic membranes and membrane reactors for separation and chemical reactors with controlled supply or removal of carbon dioxide, which will have an impact on process intensification for many industrially important separation and reactions involving carbon dioxide.  The project has resulted in publication of seven scientific papers in peer-reviewed journals.  It also effectively trained several Ph.D., master?s and undergraduate students and visiting scholars/post-doctoral fellows in membrane and chemical engineering research. The results of the project have been incorporated in course materials for teaching undergraduate and graduate students, and in the lectures delivered by the principal investigator in university seminars, workshops and technical conferences around the world. 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/16/2021
Modified by: Jerry Y.S. Lin
